journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Controlling the deformation in elastic and viscoelastic structures due to temperature and moisture changes using piezoelectric actuators

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, USA

author-notes.corresp: Anastasia Muliana, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Texas A&M University, 3123 TAMU, College Station, TX 77843, USA. Email: amuliana@tamu.edu

abstract.p: We study the placement of surface-bonded piezoelectric actuators to control or minimize the deformation due to changes in temperature and moisture content in linear elastic and linear viscoelastic cantilever beams. The effect of unsteady heat and moisture diffusion phenomena on the response characteristics of the elastic and viscoelastic beams, such as displacement, stress, and strain fields, is examined based on which the magnitude of external actuating voltage to minimize deformation is predicted. This is followed by a comparative study of the field variables in cases of actuated and unactuated beams. Finite difference method is used to solve the field equations numerically. The numerical results are corroborated by comparing the results with analytical and experimental results that are available. Relatively smaller magnitude of external actuating voltage is necessary to minimize bending in the viscoelastic structure compared to the elastic structure due to the phenomenon of stress relaxation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to lightweight, low manufacturing cost, high strength-to-weight ratio, high corrosion resistance, and ease to shape, polymer and polymer composites are widely used in spacecraft and automotive industries. Besides, the mechanical and physical properties of polymer composites can be engineered to meet the requirements of specific applications (Harper, 2002; Kutz, 2005). Structural components, while in use, undergo several cycles of mechanical loading and environmental stimuli, such as temperature and humidity changes, during their lifetime. These conditions could pose a detrimental effect on the performance of these components by causing unintended deformation or by speeding up the viscoelastic response (creep or stress relaxation1). Piezoelectric actuators offer a viable means to control and/or mitigate excessive deformation in structures and hence in prolonging their lifetime.

Several studies have been carried out to investigate the use of piezoelectric materials to minimize mechanical and thermal deformations in structures. Crawley and De Luis (1987) studied the use of surface-bonded and surface-embedded piezoelectric actuators to control the response of cantilever beam-like structures under static and dynamic loads. They presented analytical models to predict the extension, bending, and shearing in elastic beams with surface-bonded and surface-embedded piezoelectric actuators (see Crawley and Anderson, 1990). Zhou and Tiersten (1994) studied the problem of bending in simply supported laminated composite plates controlled by piezoelectric actuators. Lee and Saravanos (1996) numerically simulated the active compensation voltage required to minimize thermally induced deformation in graphite–epoxy composite beams with surface piezoelectric actuators. In practice, piezoelectric actuators are installed as patches at specific locations on the structures. Crawley and De Luis (1987) published a note on the choice of locations when such piezoelectric patches could be more effective. Ahmed and Upadhyay (2006) numerically simulated the effect of multiple piezoelectric patches to minimize the deformation in cantilever beams, and Song et al. (2004) numerically simulated the use of piezoelectric patches to minimize deformation due to thermal effects in cantilever beams and corroborated the results with experiments. All the above studies have considered only elastic response, which is time and rate independent. In many practical applications, the response of structures due to mechanical and environmental effects is often rate (time) dependent. Thus, to mitigate excessive deformation during their service time, one needs to know not only the magnitude of the applied voltage (or electric field) but also its rate.

In thermoelasticity, the thermally induced strains are accounted for by introducing the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE). Similarly, the coefficient of moisture expansion (CME) was introduced (see Bouadi and Sun, 1989; Weitsman and Cai, 1994) to account for the moisture-induced strains.2 The mechanical response of polymers and polymer composites is influenced by changes in environmental conditions, and this was studied by Weitsman (1987, 2001), Springer (1988), and Muliana et al. (2009). Under elevated temperatures and in humid environment, polymer and polymer composites exhibit pronounced viscoelastic response. Flaggs and Crossman (1981) numerically simulated the effect of temperature and moisture changes on the linearized viscoelastic response of polymer composites and corroborated it against experimental data.

In polymer and polymer composites, the coupling between heat conduction and moisture diffusion is reported to be prominent. Sih et al. (1980, 1981) reported that an uncoupled theory for the diffusion of heat and moisture is inadequate to predict the response of polymers and polymer composites. Sih et al. (1981, 1986) showed that the extent of coupling between these two phenomena is dependent on the ratio of their diffusivities and a nondimensional coupling constant both of which are material specific.
Piezoelectric actuators could offer a solution to minimize the excessive deformation in structures caused by temperature and moisture effects and mechanical loads acting simultaneously.

We numerically simulate the use of surface-bonded piezoelectric actuators to control the deformation in elastic and viscoelastic cantilever beams subjected to changes in temperature and moisture concentration during coupled heat conduction and moisture diffusion. The problem leads to three different time histories associated with the strong coupling between the diffusion of moisture, conduction of heat, and the nonlinear time-dependent deformation. Due to the electromechanical coupling effect exhibited by piezoelectric materials, changes in the deformation of the smart structures due to environmental effects and mechanical loading will generate an electric field and/or electric charges, which vary with time. In order to use piezoelectric materials in mitigating (or controlling) the deformation in smart structures under the above-mentioned conditions, it is necessary to determine time-dependent field variables in both host structure and active layer and to take into account the existence of field variables in applying time-dependent external actuating voltage. First, the time-dependent response of the unactuated cantilever beam due to temperature and moisture changes is computed. Then, an external voltage is applied across the piezoelectric layer to minimize this deformation. The following assumptions are made in this study. The response of structural materials chosen for this study is assumed to be linearly elastic or linearly viscoelastic. The electromechanical response of the piezoelectric material is assumed to be linear. Cantilever beam geometry is chosen for this study, for simplicity, and aging of the material due to hostile environment is not considered. The effect of temperature and moisture on the deformation of the beam is incorporated through CTE and CME. It is assumed that the elastic material properties do not depend on the temperature and moisture concentration, for simplicity. The viscoelastic material is assumed to be thermorheologically simple (TSM)3 with shift factor dependent on both temperature and moisture concentration. The cantilever beam with a surface-bonded piezoelectric actuator is shown in Figure 1. The elastic or viscoelastic layer is perfectly bonded to the piezoelectric layer resting on the top of it. The following cases are studied in this study:

list-item.p: Anisotropic carbon fiber-reinforced polymer (CFRP)–lead zirconate titanate (PZT) 5H beam assembly subjected to transient temperature and moisture concentration changes.
Isotropic unreinforced epoxy–PZT 5H beam assembly subjected to temperature and moisture concentration changes.
Linearized viscoelastic material–PZT 5H beam assembly subjected to temperature and moisture concentration changes.

caption.p: Geometry and boundary conditions for the cantilever assembly. The top layer corresponds to the PZT material and the bottom layer corresponds to the elastic or viscoelastic material. The surface containing the edge ACE is clamped, and all others are traction free.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.p: The governing equations are solved using forward-time centered-space finite difference method. The displacement and stress fields in the elastic or viscoelastic layer and voltage and electric field in the piezoelectric layer are computed as the temperature and moisture concentration evolve. To minimize the deformation of the beam due to the effect of temperature and moisture, the beam needs to be actuated by an external voltage applied through the thickness of the piezoelectric layer. The magnitude and rate of this voltage in the piezoelectric layer are predicted.

The organization of this article is as follows: In the next section, constitutive equations for the elastic and viscoelastic beams and the effect of the coupling between the diffusion of heat and moisture are briefly discussed. In the third section, the initial and boundary conditions and governing equations for the problem under consideration are documented. Finite difference method is used to solve these governing equations. Convergence and parametric studies for the coupling between heat and moisture diffusion are presented. In the fourth section, the numerical results obtained for the cases mentioned earlier are presented. In the final section, a summary of the results and concluding remarks are provided.

sec.title: Preliminaries
sec.p: The constitutive models for the elastic and viscoelastic beams due to coupled diffusion of fluid and heat conduction require the satisfaction of the balance of mass, linear and angular momenta, energy, and the second law of thermodynamics.4,5
The balance of energy for the solid constituent accounting for the coupled heat and moisture diffusion results in the following equation

sec.title: Plane strain deformation in linearized elastic and linear viscoelastic materials
sec.p:
The displacement field for plane strain deformation takes the form
u =
( u ( x , y ) , v ( x , y ) )
. For an isotropic, homogenous linearly elastic material undergoing plane strain deformation, the stress components
σ
xx
,
σ
yy
, and
σ
xy
, when expressed in terms of displacements for plane strain deformation, take the following form

where α, β, E, and
ν
^
denote the CTE, CME, Young’s modulus, and Poisson’s ratio, respectively. Balance of linear momentum for plane strain deformation in the absence of body forces leads to

Equation (16) when expressed in terms of displacements gives the governing equation for the deformation of elastic material due to moisture and temperature changes during the coupled diffusion phenomena. If body forces are ignored, they take the following form

For a class of problems in linearized viscoelasticity, solutions can be constructed from the solution of a corresponding boundary value problem in linearized elasticity provided certain conditions are satisfied (see Wineman and Rajagopal, 2000), and we shall appeal to this correspondence. The response of viscoelastic materials is strongly dependent on the changes in temperature. The stress relaxation and the creep phenomena can either be sped up or slowed down depending on the change in temperature. For simplicity, the viscoelastic material is assumed to be a TSM where the shift factor (a), which is a material property, is a function of the material temperature (θ) and the reference temperature (θo). This procedure is known as time–temperature superposition (Leaderman and Textile Foundation, 1943). Wineman and Rajagopal (2000) discuss the extension of time–temperature superposition to time varying temperature histories. Viscoelastic material behavior can also be affected due to the diffusion of a fluid in the material, such as moisture (Rajagopal and Wineman, 2010). The diffusing fluid can either soften the material or harden it. In this study, the shift factor is assumed to be a function of both temperature and moisture concentration as follows
where the intrinsic time is given as follows

Constitutive equations for viscoelastic response, incorporating thermal and moisture effects, are obtained from the corresponding equations in linearized elasticity. The summary of the equations so obtained for plane strain deformation is as follows
Similarly, the equilibrium equations that are the governing equations for the deformation of the viscoelastic material due to coupled diffusion can be summarized as follows

sec.title: Constitutive and equilibrium equations for a piezoelectric material
sec.p: The derivation of the electrothermoelastic field equations from the balance laws and the second law has been presented by Tiersten (1971). If the deformation and electric fields are assumed to be small enough and if the pyroelectric effects are ignored, the stress (T) and electric displacement (D) can be linearized as follows (Yang, 2005):

Due to lack of studies and experimental data on the effect of moisture on the response of piezoelectric materials, we shall neglect the moisture effect on the electromechanical response of piezoelectric materials. The electric field
E

. The conservation of charge and linear momentum in the absence of body charge and body force results in the following equations
Equations (22) and (23) represent the field equations employed for the piezoelectric layer of the beam assembly.

sec.title: Finite difference solution for deformation due to coupled heat conduction and moisture diffusion
sec.p: Figure 1 depicts the geometry of the cantilever beam assembly subjected to heat and moisture diffusion. For simplicity, the mechanical loading on the beam is not considered, and heat and moisture diffusion is assumed to occur only through the thickness of the beam assembly. The length (L) and thickness (h1) of the elastic or the viscoelastic layer (CDEF) are 0.5 and 0.0125 m, respectively. This forms a slender beam. This layer is assumed to be perfectly bonded to the piezoelectric layer (ABCD) of same length but of thickness (h2) = 0.0025 m. Surfaces AB and EF are maintained at 350 and 300 K, respectively. The moisture concentration on surfaces AB and EF is assumed to be 1 and 0, respectively. Moisture concentration is with reference to the weight of moisture in the solid. The moisture concentration in a solid in the saturated state is strongly dependent on the relative humidity and temperature of the surroundings (Sih et al., 1986; Wright, 1981). For instance, the amount of moisture in T300/5208 and AS/3501-5 in a saturated state is given by 0.015 × relative humidity (RH) % and 0.017 × RH % of their initial weights, respectively (Sih et al., 1986). Since the length-to-thickness ratio of the piezoelectric layer is much less than 1, the temperature and moisture changes across the piezoelectric layer are ignored, that is, the piezoelectric layer is assumed to be at uniform temperature and moisture concentration. The problem is addressed within the context of plane strain deformation, for simplicity. Boundary conditions for both layers of the beam referring to Figure 1 are summarized as follows
The continuity of the displacement and the traction along the surface CD is given as follows
where superscripts “e” and “p” refer to elastic or viscoelastic layer and piezoelectric layer, respectively. The boundary conditions for the piezoelectric layer are summarized as follows

sec.title: Coupled heat and moisture diffusion
sec.p:
Diffusion of moisture is relatively much slower than the diffusion of heat in many polymer and polymer composites. So, the ratio of temperature to moisture diffusivities Dh /Dm (defined as the Lewis number) plays a significant role in quantifying the degree of coupling between these two phenomena. Since this study is intended to capture the effect of simultaneous heat and moisture diffusion on elastic and viscoelastic responses of structures, the ratio of their diffusivities is chosen such that both these effects are predominant for the time period under consideration. From equation (14), it is observed that the interdependency of temperature and moisture fields is governed by the constants λ and ν. A parametric study is first presented in this section to determine the range of values of the Lewis number, the coupling constant (λν), and the constants ν and λ that ensure a strong coupling between these two phenomena. The coupled heat and moisture diffusion equation (14) is used with the following nondimensional parameters
u
^

t
^

where C0 = 0, θ0 = 300 K, Cf = 1, and θf = 350 K. Equation (14) subject to equation (28) transforms as follows

sec.title: Parametric study for moisture and temperature fields
sec.p:
The Lewis number (
1 /
u
^
) and the coupling constant (λν) are the material properties that quantify this coupling. The heat and moisture diffusion phenomena in polymers/polymer composites occur at different time scales, the latter phenomena being slower than the former. This is identified by comparing the thermal and moisture diffusivities of certain polymers. For instance, the Lewis number in the case of T300/5208 carbon/epoxy composite in the direction normal to the fibers is 10 (Sih et al., 1981), and it is of the order of 106 for epoxy.8 The coupling constant also differs from material to material. Hence, a parametric study is first performed in order to qualitatively study the effect of these parameters on the degree of coupling between heat and moisture diffusion. The properties of T300/5208 polymer composite are chosen for a standard case. The boundary conditions used for the parametric study are given in the section titled “Coupled heat and moisture diffusion.”

It is observed from the parametric study that when
u
^
<< 1 (
e
. g .
u
^
=
10
− 6
)
, for instance, in epoxy, the effect of moisture diffusion on the diffusion of heat is negligible irrespective of the value of coupling constant λν. Moisture diffusion, on the contrary, is strongly dependent on heat diffusion through the constant λ. A more detailed discussion of the coupling coefficient in the diffusion process can be found in Ramachandra (2011).

When
u
^
is comparable to 1 (
e
. g .
u
^
= 0 . 1
) like in a carbon epoxy composite, the degree of coupling between heat and moisture diffusion is prominent. The interdependence of both the diffusive phenomena is strongly governed by the values of λ and ν. Figure 3(a) represents the temperature and moisture fields for the values of λ =0.122 and ν =2.05. From Figure 3(b) and (c), it is observed that when the values of λ and ν are changed by an order of magnitude from their base values, both temperature and moisture fields are significantly affected. Figure 3(d) is obtained when the value of λν is reduced by one order of magnitude from its base value. From Figure 3, it is observed that the dependency of heat diffusion on moisture diffusion is not affected by a decrease in the value ν from its base value. However, any increase from its base value is reflected as an observable change in the temperature profile. On the contrary, moisture diffusion is sensitive to both increase and decrease of the value of λ from its base value. From the parametric studies, it is observed that the coupling between heat and moisture diffusion increases with an increase in
u
^
. Also, it is observed from Figure 3 that when
u
^
= 0 . 1
, the coupling constant λν and the constants λ and ν are at their base values, and the coupling is significant. Therefore, the following choice of constants is made for the problem under study

sec.title: Finite difference formulation of the field equations for a linear viscoelastic material
sec.p: In this section, the finite difference equations for the field equations derived in the section titled “Constitutive and governing equations” are presented. When dealing with viscoelastic materials, it is necessary to incorporate the history of loading in determining the response of the material at current time. During the diffusion process, the deformation and stress fields change with time, which influence the response of the material at a later time. At a fixed time tm, the first term of equation (21) can be expanded as follows (see Muliana and Rajagopal, 2011, for a detailed discussion)
where
The spatial derivatives are approximated as follows

where i and j denote the node numbers along the x and y directions, respectively, and
ζ
denotes a field variable such as a displacement component or voltage. Referring to equation (35), at a time instant tm, the stresses in equation (20) can be approximated as follows

where
ℑ = [

s
(

m
−

k + 1
) −

s
(
ϕ
m
−
ϕ

) ]
. The spatial derivatives can be expanded by appealing to equations (37) and (38). Similarly, the other stress components in equation (21) and governing equations given through equation (22) can be approximated by their finite difference formulations. For instance, the first governing equation given through (21) is expanded as follows

sec.title: Convergence study
sec.p:
An unreinforced epoxy–PZT 5H beam is chosen as a test case for the convergence study. The material properties of epoxy resin and PZT 5H are summarized in Table 1. The y direction is taken as the poling direction of PZT layer as shown in Figure 1. Following the parametric study, it was mentioned that the coupled heat and moisture diffusion equations shall be solved by choosing the values of
u
^
= 0 . 1
and
λ = 0 . 122
. The boundary conditions to which the beam assembly is subjected to are summarized in the section titled “Coupled heat and moisture diffusion.” The grid sizes considered for the convergence study are summarized in Table 2. With this choice of materials and grid sizes, the finite difference equations obtained from the previous section are solved simultaneously.

caption.p: Summary of the properties of epoxy (Harper, 2002)

fn.p: CTE: coefficient of thermal expansion; CME: coefficient of moisture expansion.

caption.p: Summary of the tip displacement of the beam and voltage across PZT layer at θ = 0.0058 for various grid sizes

sec.p: Figure 4 depicts the corresponding vertical displacement, voltage across the PZT 5H layer, and the axial stress at half-length of the beam for various grid sizes. The tip vertical displacement and potential difference at half-length for all the grid sizes are summarized in Table 2. For the grid sizes in the second and third rows of Table 2, it is observed that the tip vertical displacement and the voltage values differ by less than 5%. The accuracy of the results can be improved by further decreasing the grid size. But, a further increase in the accuracy is accompanied by much greater increase in the computational time and cost. Hence, the grid size specified in the third row shall be considered for the current study. It is noted that the large lateral deformation is due to a large curvature of the slender beam; the strains experienced by the material are close to 0.02. Figure 5 illustrates the corresponding axial and transverse strains of the epoxy–PZT smart beam. The reported strains are measured in the middle of the beam through the height of the beam. The magnitude of the maximum strain is about 0.02. Based on a rough calculation for a deformation gradient of 0.02, the percent error in the calculated strain for neglecting the second-order term of the deformation gradient is about 1%. Whether this 1% error is acceptable depends on the error tolerance given to the specific problem. It is noted that the main intention of this article is to provide an analysis in controlling or mitigating the deformation in smart elastic and viscoelastic beams due to continuous changes in the temperature and moisture concentration using piezoelectric materials. We start with a rather simple constitutive model, namely the linearized electromechanical constitutive model, and study the effect of fully coupled hygrothermal behavior on the time-dependent electromechanical response of smart beams.

sec.p: The results predicted by numerical simulations are first compared with the experimental study presented in the study given by Song et al. (2004). Figure 6(a) depicts the geometry used by Song et al. (2004). It is slightly modified for use with the computer program as depicted in Figure 6(b). The properties of the elastic and piezoelectric layers are summarized in Tables 3 and 4, respectively. Same boundary conditions are assumed for both geometries as shown in Figure 6. The steady-state temperature field is assumed in the composite beam. Figure 7 compares the numerically evaluated vertical displacement of the beam due to temperature gradient to that reported in Song et al. (2004), for both the actuated and the unactuated states. The tip displacement of the unactuated beam, predicted numerically, is 11.46 mm compared to 11 mm as reported in Song et al. (2004). Hence, there is a good agreement between both the theoretical predictions and the experimental results. The numerically calculated actuating voltage is 45 V as compared to 150 V reported in Song et al. (2004). The difference in the magnitudes of both the voltages could be attributed to the modified geometry, since the length of actuator in the modified geometry is greater than that of the original. Additionally, in the geometry considered by Song et al. (2004), part of the actuation is performed by PZT 5A, which is weaker than PZT 5H for actuation purposes. This justifies why a lesser voltage is required in the former case. It is observed from Figure 7 that the displacement is suppressed more in the region where PZT actuators are attached.

caption.p: Plot (a) illustrates the geometry used by Song et al. Plot (b) depicts the modified geometry used in the current study: (a) composite beam with three PZT 5H actuators and one PZT 5A sensor and (b) composite beam with PZT 5H surface-bonded actuator.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.
Summary of the properties of the elastic layer (Song et al., 2004)
Summary of the properties of PZT 5H (Yang, 2005)

Comparison of the vertical displacement obtained numerically to that reported in Song et al. (2004) for the beam in actuated and unactuated states. Curves highlighted by (“o”) depict the results reported in Song et al. (2004).

sec.title: Numerical solutions to the cases considered in the study
sec.p: In this section, field variables are obtained numerically with the appropriate boundary conditions for the choice of materials discussed earlier in section “Introduction.” The dimensions of the beam assembly are summarized in Figure 1. The PZT 5H layer is assumed to be poled along the y direction.

sec.title: CFRP–PZT 5H beam assembly under transient temperature and moisture changes
sec.p:
The material properties of CFRP and PZT 5H are summarized in Tables 4 and 5, respectively. Due to the the inherent anisotropy of CFRP, the elastic modulus, the CTE, and the CME are different along the fiber-reinforcement direction and the direction normal to it. Along the fiber direction, CFRP exhibits higher elastic modulus but much lower CTE and CME compared to the transverse direction. The moisture diffusivity of CFRP composites in the transverse direction is temperature dependent (Wright, 1981). The Lewis number of 10 (
u
^
= 0 . 1
) is used in this analysis, following the property of T300/5208 epoxy composite as reported in Sih et al. (1981). In this case, the evolution of temperature and moisture concentration in the beam is depicted in Figure 8.

caption.p: Summary of the properties of CFRP (Harper, 2002)

tr.td: CTE along transverse direction (mm/mm/K) α2 = α3
CME along fiber direction (mm/mm/% H2O) β1
CME along transverse direction (mm/mm/% H2O) β2 = β3

fn.p: CTE: coefficient of thermal expansion; CME: coefficient of moisture expansion.

caption.p:
Evolution of (a) moisture concentration and (b) temperature in a CFRP layer with time. The dimensionless time parameter
t
^
varies from 0 to 7 × 10−2. t↑ indicates evolution of time.
CFRP: carbon fiber-reinforced polymer.

sec.p: Figure 9(b) compares the vertical displacement in unactuated and actuated beams. The CFRP beam exhibits linear elastic behavior. It is observed that the displacement in the latter case has been subdued to a great extent. Figure 9(c) depicts the axial stress at half-length of the beam assembly. It is observed that at the CFRP–PZT 5H interface, the axial stress is discontinuous due to material discontinuity. Due to the bending of the beam toward the PZT 5H layer, it is observed that higher compressive stresses are present in the CFRP layer as we move from the bottom surface of the beam to the common interface between the two layers. Figure 9(d) depicts the axial stress at half-length of the beam assembly when actuated externally. It is observed that the axial stresses are reduced in the presence of an actuating voltage. Figures 9(e) and (f) depict the shear stress at half-length of the unactuated and actuated beams, respectively. It is observed that the shear stresses are considerably reduced due to external actuation. Figures 10(a) and (b) depict the evolution of electric field and voltage induced across the PZT layer due to thermal and moisture changes in the beam. Figures 10(c) and (d) represent the actuating voltage and the corresponding electric field required to minimize the bending of the beam due to temperature and moisture changes.

caption.p: Evolution of vertical displacement, axial, and shear stresses in CFRP–PZT 5H beam due to temperature and moisture changes in the actuated and unactuated states. t↑ indicates evolution of time: (a) vertical displacement in an unactuated beam, (b) vertical displacement in an actuated beam, (c) axial stress at half-length in an unactuated beam, (d) axial stress at half-length in an actuated beam, (e) shear stress at midsection in an unactuated beam, and (f) shear stress at midsection in an actuated beam.
CFRP: carbon fiber-reinforced polymer; PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

Evolution of electric field E and voltage across the PZT 5H layer in actuated and unactuated states of a CFRP–PZT 5H beam subjected to changes in the temperature and moisture concentration. t↑ indicates evolution of time: (a) electric field induced across a PZT 5H layer due to bending, (b) potential difference induced across a PZT 5H layer due to bending, (c) actuating voltage required across PZT 5H with time, and (d) electric field required across PZT 5H with time.
CFRP: carbon fiber-reinforced polymer; PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.title: Elastic and viscoelastic epoxy–PZT 5H beams subjected to transient thermal and moisture fields
sec.p: In this section, the response characteristics of a linearly elastic and a linearly viscoelastic epoxy–PZT beams subjected to changes in temperature and moisture concentration are presented. The finite difference equations (21) and (22) are used for this purpose. The polymer composite material is assumed to be TSM, for simplicity. Material properties of the polymer and PZT 5H materials are summarized in Tables 1 and 4. For simplicity, the stress relaxation modulus of the polymer due to hygrothermal effect is assumed to have the following form

where “a” represents the shift factor. Initial temperature θo and moisture concentration Co are chosen as 300 K and 0, respectively. The shift factor is assumed to be the following function of temperature θ and concentration C

where the constants k1 = 2.7 and k2 = 0.459.9 The relaxation modulus is
E
s
=
E
o
( 1 +
e
t /
t
o
)
, where E0 = 1.75 GPa. The relaxation time to for the viscoelastic epoxy is chosen as 3000 s, so that it is of the same order of magnitude as the time taken for the temperature and moisture fields to reach steady state. This is done to incorporate long-term relaxation response in a viscoelastic material. Figures 11(a) and (b) depict the evolution of temperature and moisture fields in elastic and viscoelastic epoxy layers with time.

caption.p:
Evolution of (a) moisture concentration and (b) temperature in elastic/viscoelastic epoxy layer with time. The dimensionless time paramete
t
^
that varies from 0 to 7 × 10−2. t↑ indicates evolution of time.

sec.p: Figures 12(a) and (b) show the vertical displacement in the actuated and unactuated elastic and viscoelastic beams, respectively. It is observed that the tip vertical displacement increases with time in the elastic beam. In the case of the viscoelastic beam, it decreases initially reaching a minimum value due to stress relaxation and then increases to reach a steady value. The axial and shear stresses are shown in Figures 12 and 13, respectively. From Figures 12(c) and 13(d), it is observed that the axial and shear stresses in viscoelastic beam are lesser than those in the elastic beam. This can be attributed to the stress relaxation phenomena. It is also observed that in the presence of external actuating voltage, both these stresses are largely suppressed. The electric field developed across the PZT 5H layer in the unactuated and actuated elastic and viscoelastic beams is also examined. The electric field in the PZT 5H layer varies largely along the length with the maximum value occurring at the fixed end. It is observed that the more the tip displacement in the unactuated beam, the more the external electric field necessary to minimize it. The actuating voltage required to minimize bending in these two cases is depicted in Figure 14(a) and (b). It is also observed that the magnitude of the electric field developed across the PZT 5H layer is well over the range in which linearized theory can be appealed to. This is because the CTE of epoxy and PZT 5H differ by two orders of magnitude, and therefore, the bending of the beam due to temperature and moisture changes is very pronounced. As a result, high electric fields are required to minimize this bending. In practice, electric fields of the order of 1 MV/m in a piezoelectric material lead the system to the verge of nonlinearity, in which case the problem needs to be addressed within the context of a nonlinear theory. The present study aims at understanding the effects of elastic and viscoelastic material response during the diffusion process on the magnitude and rate of the electric potential that should be applied in order to mitigate the deformation. This study can be used as a first step toward more a realistic situation that incorporates the nonlinear response.

caption.p: Evolution of the vertical displacement and axial stress in elastic and viscoelastic epoxy beams in the unactuated and actuated states: (a) vertical displacement of an elastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam in actuated and unactuated states, (b) vertical displacement of a viscoelastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam in actuated and unactuated states, (c) axial stress at half-length in an unactuated elastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam, (d) axial stress at half-length in an actuated elastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam, (e) axial stress at half-length in an unactuated viscoelastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam, and (f) axial stress at half-length in an actuated viscoelastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam. t↑ indicates evolution of time from 0 to 1800 s with Δt = 70 s.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

Evolution of shear stress in elastic and viscoelastic epoxy beams subjected to changes in the temperature and the moisture concentration in the actuated and unactuated states: (a) shear stress at half-length in an unactuated elastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam, (b) shear stress at half-length in an actuated elastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam, (c) shear stress at half-length in an unactuated viscoelastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam, and (d) shear stress at half-length in an actuated viscoelastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam. t↑ indicates evolution of time.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

External actuating voltage required with time to minimize bending in elastic and viscoelastic beams subjected to changes in the temperature and moisture concentration: (a) actuating voltage required across a PZT 5H layer for an epoxy–PZT 5h beam and (b) comparison of the actuating voltage required for an elastic and a viscoelastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The implementation of perfectly bonded surface piezoelectric actuators to minimize the temperature- and moisture-induced deformation in elastic and viscoelastic cantilever beams was studied. The solutions for linearized viscoelastic response were obtained by appealing to the correspondence principle. Finite difference method was used to solve the governing equations, and the numerical method was corroborated against analytical and experimental results. The response of CFRP, elastic and viscoelastic epoxy, due to the diffusion of heat and moisture was studied. The external actuating voltage required across a PZT 5H layer to minimize the bending of these beams was obtained based on this response. In the case of elastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam, the tip displacement increases steadily to reach a constant value as the temperature and moisture fields evolve. In the case of the CFRP–PZT 5H beam, the tip displacement is observed to decrease to a steady-state value, while in the case of the viscoelastic epoxy–PZT 5H beam, it decreases initially and then increases to reach a steady-state value. In the former case, this is attributed to the anisotropy of the CFRP material, whereas for the latter case, it is attributed to the time- and temperature-dependent response of the viscoelastic layer. Due to lower bending in the viscoelastic epoxy beam than in elastic epoxy beam, a relatively lesser actuating voltage is required to minimize bending. During the coupled diffusion process in viscoelastic materials, where the response varies significantly with time, it is also necessary to consider the rate of applied voltage in addition to its magnitude in mitigating the deformation using piezoelectric materials.

ack.p: Chaitanya Kuravi is thankful to Dr Satish Karra for his useful inputs toward this study.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This study has been sponsored by AFOSR under the grant FA9550-10-1-0002.
The continued straining or flow of a material under a constant stress is called creep, whereas the decrease in stress at constant strain is called stress relaxation (Wineman and Rajagopal, 2000).
Such a notion is restricted to small deformation problems.

If the change in the viscoelastic behavior of a material is equivalent to a corresponding shift in the logarithmic time scale, the body is categorized as a thermorheologically simple material (TSM; see Schwarzl and Starverman, 1952). For such materials, the shift factor is a material property and a function of the reference temperature and current temperature.

One could develop the governing equations for the problem within the context of the Mechanics of Mixtures (see Atkin and Crane, 1976; Bowen, 1982; Rajagopal and Tao, 1995; Truesdell, 1957a, 1957b). Such an approach however leads to a very complicated set of coupled partial differential equations with inherent difficulties with regard to the specification of boundary conditions for the constituents of the mixture. In view of this, we shall adopt a more simplified approach that is given in this study.
It is assumed that the relative velocity of the fluid with respect to the solid is small enough to be ignored.
By setting the constants k12 and k21 to zero, equations (10) and (11) reduce to Fourier’s heat conduction and Fickian’s diffusion equations, respectively.
The Dufour effect is defined as the heat flux due to moisture concentration changes. The Soret effect is defined as the mass flux due to temperature changes.
This is calculated from the properties of epoxy summarized in Table 1.
For this choice of k1 and k2, the shift factor is reduced to 1/10 for temperature rise of 50 K and C = 1.
